# corporate governance

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority, as Hong Kong’s central bank institutions, fully understands the importance of good governance for maintaining and upholding public confidence in the HKMA fulfilling its statutory responsibilities, and therefore continues its efforts to uphold high standards of corporate governance.

To facilitate the commitment to good corporate governance, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority:

Developed a well-defined corporate governance framework;
Maintaining high accountability and transparency, and in co-operation with stakeholders, maintaining closely linked relations; and
Implementing robust controls measures to manage risk(s), and ensure all staff at all levels’ behaviours and their day-to-day operations meet specified standards.

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority’s governance framework covers several key measures, including Advisory Committees that provide advice and guidance, accountability and transparency, as well as internal controls and external audit.

# The HKMA and SAR government

The Monetary Authority is part of the Hong Kong Special Administrative Region Government (SAR Government) framework, but can hire staff with different employment terms to attract talent with appropriate experience and specialized knowledge. The Chief Executive of the Monetary Authority and its staff are all People’s staff. The day-to-day operations of the Monetary Authority are highly autonomous within the scope of powers vested or delegated to the Monetary Authority.

The Financial Secretary is responsible for determining Hong Kong’s monetary policy objective and monetary structure: in letters from the Financial Secretary to the Monetary Authority on June 25, 2003, it provides that stability shall be maintained through the currency issuance system, keeping the Hong Kong dollar exchange rate around 7.80 Hong Kong dollars to 1 US dollar. The Monetary Authority is responsible on his own to achieve the monetary policy objective, including deciding related strategy, tools, and method, and has responsibility for maintaining the stability and soundness of Hong Kong’s monetary system.

The Financial Secretary, with the assistance of the Financial Affairs and Treasury Bureau Director, has responsibility for maintaining Hong Kong’s financial system's stability and integrity, as well as maintaining Hong Kong’s status as an international financial centre. To implement these policies, the Monetary Authority’s mandate includes:

- Promote the overall stability and effective operations of the banking sector;
- Collaborate with other related institutions and organisations to develop the debt market;
- Handle matters related to the issuance and circulation of statutory banknotes and coins;
- Through development of Payment, clearing and settlement systems, and being responsible for operating related systems where appropriate, promote the safety and efficiency of financial infrastructure; and
- Collaborate with other related institutions and organisations to promote confidence in Hong Kong’s monetary and financial system, and implement appropriate market development measures to assist in strengthening Hong Kong’s international competitiveness.

The Exchange Fund is under the control of the Financial Secretary. The Monetary Authority shall, according to the powers delegated by the Financial Secretary, be responsible to the Financial Secretary for the management and investment of the Exchange Fund.

# Advisory Committees and management.

# Advisory Committee

Advisory Committees provide advice and guidance on the Financial Services and Markets Authority’s main areas of work.

The Exchange Fund Advisory Committee was established under the Exchange Fund Bill, to provide advice to the Financial Secretary on matters related to the exercise of control over the Exchange Fund. The Financial Secretary is the ex-officio Chairman of the Exchange Fund Advisory Committee, and other members (including the Monetary Authority) are appointed by the Financial Secretary on authority from the Chief Executive of the Hong Kong Special Administrative Region in a personal capacity. The members are appointed based on their professional knowledge and experience, to effect broad benefits for the Exchange Fund Advisory Committee. Under the Exchange Fund Advisory Committee, there are five specialist committees responsible for monitoring the work of the Hong Kong Monetary Authority in sector-specific areas and providing advice, and for reporting to and making recommendations to the Financial Secretary through the Advisory Committee. For further details on the Exchange Fund Advisory Committee and its five specialist committees, see pages 53 to 63.

The Banking Business Advisory Committees and Deposit-taking Companies Advisory Committee provide advice to the Chief Executive of the Hong Kong Special Administrative Region regarding the Banking Ordinance, particularly matters related to banks, deposit-taking companies, and restricted license banks operating banking business or taking deposits (depending on the situation). Both committees are chaired by the Financial Secretary, and members include the Monetary Authority and individuals appointed by the Chief Executive’s empowering authorization. For further details on the Banking Business Advisory Committee and Deposit-taking Companies Advisory Committee, see pages 64 to 65.

# Management

The Chief Executive Committee is composed of the Chairman of the Hong Kong Monetary Authority, the Deputy Chief Executive, and other high-level staff, and the Chairman of the Hong Kong Monetary Authority serves as Chairman. The Chief Executive Committee will regularly launch meetings, report to the Chief Executive on the progress of the main work of the Hong Kong Monetary Authority’s departments, and provide advice to the Chief Executive on related policy issues concerning the operations of the Hong Kong Monetary Authority. See pages 66 to 67 for the list of Chief Executive Committee members.

# Accountability and transparency

Regarding the methods adopted for day-to-day operations and implementing Government objectives, the Monetary Authority has consistently maintained a high degree of autonomy, and is complemented by high accountability and transparency.

The Monetary Authority is appointed by the Financial Secretary, therefore the Hong Kong Monetary Authority has responsibility to the public through the Financial Secretary; and because the powers of the Hong Kong Monetary Authority are determined by laws passed by the Legislative Council, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority also has responsibility to the public through the Legislative Council. The Hong Kong Monetary Authority also recognises itself as bearing a more extensive responsibility, to promote public understanding of the Monetary Authority’s role and objectives, and to closely monitor issues of concern to personnel. In its execution of day-to-day work and maintaining broad linkages with society, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority steadfastly strives to enhance transparency and maintain open policies. This policy has two objectives:

- In ensuring the financial community and the public have a full understanding of the work of the Hong Kong Monetary Authority, while taking into consideration the statutory limits on disclosure of commercial confidentiality and confidential data; and
- ensure that the Hong Kong Monetary Authority maintains in touch with the pulse of society and provide an appropriate response to public opinion.

# Communicate with the Public

The HKMA strives to promote monetary and banking sector stability, effectively manage official Reserves, develop and monitor resilient and diversified financial infrastructure, thereby consolidating Hong Kong’s international financial centre status and promote Hong Kong’s economic development.

The Monetary Authority shall effectively fulfill its responsibilities by gaining the trust of personnel. Therefore, the Monetary Authority, with a rigorous attitude, fulfills its responsibility to communicate its policies and work to the public. The Monetary Authority maintains extensive contacts with media and leverage social media platforms to communicate more effectively with the public in the digital era. The Monetary Authority also strives to handle issues involving the Monetary Authority’s scope of responsibilities that are of significant public concern, particularly through traditional and social media to clarify inaccurate information and rumors related to Monetary Authority policies.

此外，金管局辦事處 equipped with an Information Centre, is divided into a library and an exhibition area, open to the public six days a week for visiting and use. See chapter "Functions of corporate institutions" (pages 185 to 191) for more details related to the work of communications and linkages between the 金管局 and the public.

# Legislative Council

The relationship between the Monetary Authority and the Legislative Council is very important for enhancing accountability and transparency. The Chief Executive of the Monetary Authority has promised to provide reports presented to the Financial Affairs Committee of the Legislative Council three times a year, briefing on various work and policies of the Monetary Authority, and answering related questions. Briefings provided by the Chief Executive to the Financial Affairs Committee are published on the Monetary Authority website.

Besides, representatives of the Hong Kong Monetary Authority regularly attend Legislative Council Committee and sub-committee meetings to explain and discuss Special matters, and assist Members in reviewing draft legislation.

# Information disclosure

hkma strives to achieve international highest standards in transparency, publishing various bilingual journals and special publications. The hkma’s bilingual website (www.hkma.gov.hk) carries a dedicated session shown economic research, data, supervisory resources, consumer information and other topics, and also carries a large amount of documents from hkma published publications, press releases, speeches and briefing session reports.

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority periodically reviews whether the disclosure of the Exchange Fund and Currency Board’s data is adequate. The Hong Kong Monetary Authority participated in the International Monetary Fund’s “Special Data Dissemination Standard” initiative for central bank’s starting in 1999. The Hong Kong Monetary Authority also publishes the record of meetings under the Advisory Committees on Currency Board, and the report on the operation of the Currency Board’s system. Since 1996, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority’s website carries banking sector regulatory policy and guidance.

# Internal controls and external audit

The Monetary Authority adopts resilient and effective controls, ensuring staff conduct with high standards, prudent risk management, and adequate checks and balances. Internal and external audit functions provide independent assessment of the adequacy and effectiveness of the control mechanisms.

# Code of conduct

The Code of Conduct offers guidance to staff on ethical and legal responsibilities, ensuring the behaviours of all staff at all levels meet specified standards.

# Internal controls

# Operations controls

As the first line of risk management, all departments and divisions have a responsibility to identify and assess the risks of their work processes, and develop proper controls to ensure the day-to-day operations of the Financial Supervisory Agency are stable.

# Corporate risk management

Risk management also takes place at the corporate level. The Risk Committee, chaired by the Chief Executive, serves as one of the cornerstones of the institutional risk management framework.

The Risk Committee reviews and reports on the potential and new risks identified by various departments, as well as whether the related controls and mitigating strategies are sufficient, and determines appropriate follow-up action.

# Internal audit

The HKMA’s internal audit department independently assess the governance procedures, risk management, and control measures of different departments to determine their adequacy and effectiveness, and to issue recommendations for improvement.

# external audit

According to section 7 of the Exchange Fund Ordinance, the financial statements of the Exchange Fund are audited by the Hong Kong SAR Government Audit Commission. The Audit Commission does not charge costs for this service. The audited Exchange Fund financial statements are published in the HKMA annual report.

# Economic and financial environment

Hong Kong’s economy recorded moderate growth in 2024, primarily driven by a turnaround in merchandise exports benefiting from improved external demand and the rebound of the global technology cycle. The labour market remained resilient, and inflation maintained a moderate level amid further decline in external price pressures. Hong Kong’s stock market rebounded significantly, while the property market was largely soft due to pressures in a sustained high interest rates environment. Given the continued escalation of trade tensions, it is expected that Hong Kong’s economy will face a challenging external environment in 2025. However, proactive economic stimulus measures launched by mainland China, together with multifaceted support provided to local enterprises, should consolidate business confidence. Hong Kong will continue to strengthen international cooperation and collaboration, and deepen regional cooperation.

# Economic review

# Real-world economic activity

Hong Kong’s economy grew moderately in 2024. Real gross domestic product, following a 3.2% increase recorded in 2023, rose year on year by 2.5% in 2024 (Table 1 and Chart 1). Externally, merchandise exports recovered and registered positive growth, supported by providing the impetus of improved external demand and the recovery of the global technology cycle, becoming a major driving force for overall economic growth. Exports of services also continued to grow further, along with the continued recovery of Hong Kong tourism, and cross-boundary financial and fundraising activity significantly increasing in the second half of the year. However, as service imports rose significantly amid continued growth in outbound tourism, they offset the positive effect of service exports on overall economic growth. Locally, private consumption expenditure softened under the changing consumption model of Hong Kong residents. Conversely, increased property transactions and an improvement in the business climate under a gradual relax of monetary conditions drove a slight increase in overall investment expenditure.

# Inflation and labour markets

Although newly signed private residential rental income gradually increases, local cost pressures remain generally manageable, together with outer price pressures gradually decreasing, local inflation in 2024 remains moderate (Chart 2). For the whole year as a whole in 2024, the basic and overall inflation rate were 1.1% and 1.7% respectively.

The labour market performed resiliently in 2024, with the unemployment rate hovering between 2.9% and 3.1% throughout the year (Chart 3). Since the first quarter, the total number of employed people (Chart 3) has steadily increased, and the labour population has also seen an increase, reflecting that labour demand and supply have generally remained stable. At the same time, with the economy continued growth, nominal wages and labour income have both recorded robust growth. Furthermore, the Government announced further enhancements to Hong Kong’s Scheme to attract talent in the 2024 Policy Report, in order to alleviate manpower shortages in different industries and to inject new impetus into the local population by attracting more young people.

# Stock market

Hong Kong's stock market significantly shifted in 2024, following a substantial rebound since mid-September. Specifically, with the US Federal Reserve reducing interest rates and the Mainland launching proactive economic stimulus measures, market sentiment significantly improved, driving the Hang Seng Index to its year-high on October 7th, closing at 23,100 points (Figure 4). However, the US presidential election held in early November triggered concerns about global economic prospects and the pace of monetary policy relaxations by the Federal Reserve, causing a slight pullback in Hong Kong's stock market. Nevertheless, the Hang Seng Index closed at 20,060 points at the end of the year, a substantial increase of 17.7% compared to the end of 2023, ending a streak of annual declines for four years.

# Property Market

Residential property market was largely soft in the first three months of 2024, but showed signs of stabilization in the fourth quarter. Supported by the relaxation of related policy measures in late February and mid-October, and the easing cycle that began in September, whole year residential transactions surged by 23.5% from the record-low of 43,002 transactions in 2023 to 53,099 in 2024. However, persistently high mortgage interest rates and accumulated inventory in the primary market continue to put downward pressure on property prices. Therefore, property prices fell year on year by 7.1%, and affordability also slightly improved, although it remains relatively tight. The non-residential property market remains soft. Among them, the vacancy rate of office buildings remains high in the situation of robust supplies, while retail shops face challenges brought about by the changing consumption model of visitors and local residents.

# economic prospects

# economic environment

Given the ongoing trade tensions and the likelihood of disruptions to international trade and capital, Hong Kong’s economy is expected to face a challenging external environment in 2025. However, related authorities and the banking sector continue to provide multifaceted support, which should enhance the resilience of local corporations. Mainland proactively launches economic stimulus measures and achieves significant breakthroughs in emerging technology areas, also bolstering business confidence. At the same time, Hong Kong will further deepen regional cooperation and speed up linkages with emerging markets. Simultaneously, with Mainland authorities’ supportive tourism policy for Hong Kong, and the Government’s continued efforts to support Hong Kong’s tourism industry, the tourism sector is expected to grow further.

# Inflation and labour markets

We expect local inflation to remain moderate in 2025. As rental income increases gradually transmit to consumer prices, local costs may face mild pressure. However, despite the increased uncertainty of global prospects, external price pressures should be moderate. On the other hand, the labour market may face challenges due to heightened trade tensions. However, various talent attraction schemes should help continue to establish a quality talent pool, providing support for long-term economic development.

# banking sector performance

Hong Kong’s banking sector remains resilient in 2024, with banks’ capital and liquidity both robust. Amid a macroeconomic environment full of (context: challenging... environment), the banking sector faced increasing credit risks during the year, but the overall asset quality remains manageable. Driven by gains from investments held for trading and increasing fee and commission income, retail bank profitability grew further compared to 2023.

# asset quality

The banking sector’s classified loan ratio increased from 1.57% as at the end of 2023 to 1.96% as at the end of 2024, and the ratio of overdue and restructured loans increased from 1.24% to 1.55% during the same period (Figure 5). The increase in the classified loan ratio was mainly due to lowered ratings of loans to some Mainland real estate developers, as well as local small and medium-sized developers and investors. However, the sector-specific classified loan ratio of related loans in Mainland China decreased from 2.58% as at the end of 2023 to 2.38% as at the end of 2024. Bank provisions remain sufficient. As at the end of 2024, the bank’s credit loan provisioning coverage ratio (i.e., the ratio of credit loan provisions and classified loans) was about 65%. If the realizable value of collateral is deducted from the non-performing loan balance, the adjusted bank credit loan provisioning coverage ratio is approximately 145%. At the same time, the delinquency ratio of residential mortgage loans and credit card loans as at the end of 2024 remained at a low level, at 0.11% and 0.35% respectively (Figure 6).

# Profitability

Profit growth was primarily due to gains from investments held for trading (+97.0%) and increases in fee and commission income (+15.4%), but part of the increase was offset by a decrease in net interest income (–5.2%). The retail bank’s net interest margin narrowed from 1.67% in 2023 to 1.52% in 2024 (Chart 8). # Balance sheet trends

The banking sector balance sheet expanded 4.3% in 2024, primarily due to increasing tradable instruments (+13.4%). Due to still-high borrowing costs, loan demand was under pressure, and the total loan amount decreased 2.8% in 2024. Among these, loans used in Hong Kong and loans used outside Hong Kong decreased by 2.1% and 5.7%, respectively, while trade finance increased 4.6%. Related loans to Mainland China decreased 8.7% in 2024.

# 貨幣穩定

儘管美國貨幣政策走向、環球增長前景及地緣政治局勢緊張存在不明朗因素港元外匯及貨幣市場繼續保持暢順有序。港元匯率在2024年首四個月回軟，然後在年內其餘時間轉強。在聯繫匯率制度下，香港銀行同業拆息大致跟隨美元利率的走勢，同時亦受本地供求情況影響。作為香港貨幣及金融穩定的基石，聯繫匯率制度一直展現強大抵禦外來衝擊的能力。

# 目標

香港貨幣政策的主要目標是維持貨幣穩定，即確保港元匯價穩定，使港元在外匯市場兌美元的匯率保持在7.75至7.85港元兌1美元的區間內。該貨幣體制主要採用貨幣發行局制度，規定由外匯基金所持的美元儲備向貨幣基礎提供最少百分之百的支持；貨幣基礎若有變動，美元儲備亦必須作出相應增減，與貨幣基礎的變動百分之百配合。

貨幣基礎（表1）包括：

- 負債證明書（為三間發鈔銀行發行的銀行紙幣提供十足支持）；
- 政府發行的流通紙幣及硬幣；
- 設於金管局的結算戶口結餘總額（即總結餘）；及
- 金管局代表政府發行的外匯基金票據及債券。

表1 貨幣基礎

金管局透過自動利率調節機制及履行兌換保證的堅決承諾來維持港元匯率的穩定。當強方（或弱方）兌換保證被觸發，金管局會應銀行要求，按每美元兌7.75港元向銀行沽出港元、買入美元（或按7.85港元買入港元、沽出美元），使總結餘增加（或減少），令港元利率下跌（或上升），從而促使港元匯率回復到7.75至7.85的兌換範圍。

# 2024年回顧

# 匯率穩定

在2024年首四個月，港元隨着流動性回軟而稍為轉弱。在4月下旬至5月中期間，主要在股息相關資金需求及股票市場交投活躍的支持下，港元匯率轉強。在8月初，由於市場一度憂慮美國經濟可能出現衰退，以及預期美國聯邦儲備局將以更快及更大幅度減息，觸發套息交易平倉及港元短倉平倉，使港元轉強至兌換保證範圍的強方。港元在9月下旬進一步走強，受惠於內地公布一系列經濟刺激措施後，本港股市交投急增。港元其後於11月初稍為轉弱，部分由於本港股市的升幅有所回落，部分則由於其時美國經濟表現強勁，給予聯邦公開市場委員會空間謹慎地調低聯邦基金利率所致。其後港元在年底季節性資金需求帶動下回升。整體而言，港元外匯市場在2024年全年繼續運作正常（圖1）。

由於年內並無觸發兌換保證，總結餘變動不大，維持在447億港元左右。與此同時，未償還外匯基金票據及債券總額由12,455億港元，稍增至13,839億港元。因此，總結餘與未償還外匯基金票據及債券總額由2023 年底的 12,904 億港元，增加至 2024 年底的 14,287億港元（圖2）。整體貨幣基礎仍然由外匯儲備提供十足支持。

# 貨幣市場

在聯繫匯率制度（聯匯制度）下，香港銀行同業拆息大致跟隨美元利率走勢，當中短期拆息亦受本地供求情況影響。隨着市場對美國政策利率下調的預期逐漸升溫，香港銀行同業拆息在2024年首八個月大致回軟（圖3）。在季末季節性資金需求及股市交投活躍的推動下，香港銀行同業拆息於9月下旬收緊，隔夜拆息於季末更一度升至6厘以上。其後香港銀行同業拆息大致穩定，至年底前因流動性相對減少而上升。全年計，隔夜、一個月及三個月香港銀行同業拆息分別下跌45、69及78基點至年底時的5.65厘、4.58厘及4.37厘。

因應美國聯邦基金利率目標區間下調，基本利率下調三次，合共一個百分點（即100基點），由5.75厘下跌至4.75厘（圖3）。在零售層面，隨着美國下調政策利率，多間銀行在9月中調低最優惠貸款利率25基點，並在11月初及12月下旬分別再調低25基點及12.5基點。在此情況下，新造按揭貸款平均利率亦由2023年的4.13厘下跌至2024年12月的3.59厘。整體而言，香港貨幣市場繼續正常運作。貼現窗借貸由2023年的388億港元增至2024年的500億港元；貼現窗的使用情況未見異常。

# 聯繫匯率制度

自1983年以來，聯匯制度一直是香港金融體系的重要支柱，展現強大應對挑戰的能力。儘管美國政策利率走向存在不確定因素，以及地緣經濟碎片化，港元外匯及貨幣市場維持有序運作，反映聯匯制度穩健有效。政府亦堅決維持聯匯制度。國際貨幣基金組織（基金組織）在《2024年對外部門報告》一再重申香港擁有具透明度的規則、龐大的財政及外匯儲備、穩健的金融規管與監管、靈活的經濟，以及審慎的財政架構，確保聯匯制度具公信力。

穩健的銀行體系對聯匯制度的正常運作具關鍵作用。香港銀行體系繼續運作暢順，流動性及資本狀況以國際標準而言均非常充裕。為確保銀行體系具備抵禦衝擊的能力，金管局一直密切監察銀行的信用、流動性與利率風險管理，以及壓力測試結果，並維持對銀行貸款的監管。

為提高貨幣發行局帳目的透明度，自1998年10月起，外匯基金已有部分資產被指定用作支持貨幣基礎。支持比率（即支持資產相對貨幣基礎的比率）由2023年底的110.73%上升至2024年9月10日的112.65%高位，超出112.5%的觸發上限（圖4），當中主要來自投資的利息及投資按市價重估。按照外匯基金諮詢委員會批准的安排，從支持組合轉撥資產至投資組合，令支持比率於9月11日降至110.08%左右。其後支持比率大致保持穩定，於12月31日收報109.56%。在聯匯制度下，雖然已指定某些外匯基金資產作為支持組合，但外匯基金的全部資產均可用作支持港元匯率。外匯基金的龐大財政資源，加上香港穩健的銀行體系，為保障香港的貨幣及金融穩定提供強而有力的後盾。

# Currency stability

Despite uncertainties regarding the US monetary policy direction, global growth prospects, and geopolitical tensions, Hong Kong’s foreign exchange and currency market continued to remain smooth and orderly. The Hong Kong dollar exchange rate softened in the first four months of 2024, and then strengthened for the rest of the year. Under the linked exchange rate system, Hong Kong bank interbank rates generally followed the trend of US dollar policy rates, while also being affected by local supply and demand situation. As a cornerstone of Hong Kong’s monetary and financial stability, the linked exchange rate system has consistently demonstrated strong resilience to withstand external shocks.

# objective

Hong Kong’s monetary policy’s main objective is to maintain currency stability, ensuring the exchange value of the Hong Kong dollar is stable, to enable the exchange rate of the Hong Kong dollar against the US dollar in the foreign exchange market to remain within the range of 7.75 to 7.85 Hong Kong dollars to 1 US dollar. This monetary structure mainly adopts the Exchange Fund system, requiring the US dollar Reserves held by the Exchange Fund to provide support for the monetary foundation of at least 100 percent; if the monetary foundation undergoes change, the US dollar Reserves must also make corresponding increases or decreases, in order to adapt to the changes in the monetary foundation by 100 percent.

Currency (Table 1) including:

- Certificate(s) of Indebtedness (fully support the bank banknotes issued by three banks);
- Government issued currency notes and coins in circulation;
- Aggregate Balance of the clearing Account established in the Financial Services and Markets Authority; and
- Bills and Notes of the Exchange Fund issued on behalf of the Government.

Table 1 Currency foundation

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority maintains the stability of the Hong Kong dollar exchange rate through an automated interest rate mechanism and its firm commitment to fulfilling the exchange assurance. When the strong-side (or weak-side) exchange assurance is triggered, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority will, at the request of banks, sell Hong Kong dollars and purchase US dollars at a rate of HK$7.75 per US dollar (or purchase Hong Kong dollars and sell US dollars at a rate of HK$7.85), to increase (or decrease) the Aggregate Balance, causing the Hong Kong dollar interest rate to drop (or rise), thereby prompting the Hong Kong dollar exchange rate to return to the exchange scope of 7.75 to 7.85.

# 2024 return

# Exchange rate stability

In the first four months of 2024, the Hong Kong dollar weakened slightly as liquidity softened. From late April to mid-May, the Hong Kong dollar strengthened, primarily supported by demand related to dividends and active stock market transactions. In early August, concerns about a potential US economic slowdown and expectations of a faster and more substantial interest rate cut by the US Federal Reserve triggered unwindings of covered interest arbitrage and short positions in the Hong Kong dollar, driving the Hong Kong dollar to the strong-side of the Convertibility Arrangement. The Hong Kong dollar subsequently strengthened further in late September, benefiting from a surge in stock market transactions in Hong Kong after Mainland China announced a range of economic stimulus measures. Subsequently, the Hong Kong dollar softened slightly in early November, partly due to a moderation in the gains in the Hong Kong stock market and partly due to the strong performance of the US economy at the time, providing the Federal Open Market Committee space to cautiously lower the Federal fund rate. Thereafter, the Hong Kong dollar rebounded amid year-end seasonal funding demand. Overall, the Hong Kong dollar foreign exchange market continued to operate normally throughout 2024 (Chart 1).

Figure 1 2024 exchange rate market

Due to does not exchange Convertibility guarantee triggered within the year, Aggregate Balance change was not large, maintaining around 447 billion Hong Kong dollar. At the same time, the total outstanding amount of Exchange Fund Bills and Notes and bonds increased slightly from 12,455 billion Hong Kong dollar to 13,839 billion Hong Kong dollar. Therefore, the Aggregate Balance and the total outstanding amount of Exchange Fund Bills and Notes and bonds increased from 12,904 billion Hong Kong dollar at the end of 2023 to 14,287 billion Hong Kong dollar at the end of 2024 (2). Overall monetary foundation still provides fully support from Exchange Fund Reserves.

Chart 2 2024 Aggregate Balance (prior to Discount Window activity) and outstanding Exchange Fund Bills and Notes and bonds.

# Currency market

Under the Linked Exchange Rate System (a linked exchange rate regime), Hong Kong’s interbank offered rate generally follows the US dollar interest rate, with short-dated rates also affected by local supply and demand conditions. As market expectations of US policy rates being lowered heat up, Hong Kong’s interbank offered rate broadly softened (Figure 3) during the first eight months of 2024. Driven by seasonal end-of-quarter funding demand and vibrant market activity, Hong Kong’s interbank offered rate tightened in late September, with overnight rates rising above 6 percent at the end of the quarter. Subsequently, Hong Kong’s interbank offered rate largely stabilized, and rose before year-end due to relatively decreased liquidity. For the whole year, overnight, one month, and three month Hong Kong interbank offered rates decreased by 45, 69, and 78 basis points to 5.65 percent, 4.58 percent, and 4.37 percent at year-end, respectively.

Following a decrease in the target range of the US Federal Fund rate, policy rates were lowered three times, totalling a one percent (or 100 basis points), from 5.75% to 4.75% (Chart 3). In the retail market, as the US lowered policy rates, multiple banks lowered their best lending rate by 25 basis points in mid-September, and further by 25 basis points and 12.5 basis points in early November and late December respectively. In this situation, the average interest rate on new mortgage loans also fell from 4.13% in 2023 to 3.59% in December 2024. Overall, Hong Kong’s currency market continues to operate normally. Borrowing through the Discount Window increased from HK$388 billion in 2023 to HK$500 billion in 2024; the usage of the Discount Window has not shown any abnormality.

Figure 3 2024 Hong Kong interbank offered rate

# linkages exchange rate system

Since 1983, the Linked exchange rate system has been an important anchor of Hong Kong’s financial system, demonstrating strong resilience to challenge(s). Despite the uncertainty surrounding US policy rates and geopolitical economic fragmentation, the Hong Kong dollar exchange and currency markets have maintained orderly operations, reflecting the Linked exchange rate system’s robust effectiveness. Government also resolutely maintains the Linked exchange rate system. The International Monetary Fund (Fund) repeatedly reiterates in its reporting on external affairs that Hong Kong has a credible set of rules, ample fiscal and external Reserves, prudent financial regulation and supervision, an agile economy, and a prudent financial framework, ensuring the Linked exchange rate system has credible.

A resilient banking sector plays a critical role in the smooth operations of the linked exchange system. Hong Kong’s banking sector continues to operate smoothly, and liquidity and capital conditions are robust according to international standards. To ensure the banking sector’s resilience to withstand shocks, the HKMA has continuously closely monitored banks’ credit, liquidity, and interest rate risk management, as well as testing results, and maintain regulatory regulation of bank loans.

To enhance the transparency of the Exchange Fund’s accounts, since October 1998, a portion of the Exchange Fund’s assets have been designated to support the monetary foundation. The support ratio (i.e., the ratio of supporting assets to the monetary foundation) rose from 110.73% at the end of 2023 to a high of 112.65% on September 10, 2024, exceeding the trigger limit of 112.5% (Figure 4), primarily due to interest from investments and revaluation of investments at market prices. Following arrangements approved by the Advisory Committees, assets were allocated from the support portfolio to the investment portfolio, bringing the support ratio down to approximately 110.08% on September 11. Subsequently, the support ratio remained largely stable, closing at 109.56% on December 31. Under the Linked Exchange Rate System, although certain Exchange Fund assets have been designated as part of the support portfolio, all of the Exchange Fund’s assets can be used to support the Hong Kong dollar exchange rate. The Exchange Fund’s ample financial resources, together with Hong Kong’s resilient banking sector, provide a strong and robust backing for protecting Hong Kong’s monetary and financial stability.

# Currency research

In 2024, the Hong Kong Monetary Research Centre (Research Centre) under the Academy, responsible for research work, published 15 research papers on monetary and financial topics of strategic importance to Hong Kong and within the region, and through five periods of open accessibility, share research achievements with global readers via electronic journals. # 銀行體系穩定

儘管面對宏觀經濟挑戰及地緣政治的不確定性，香港銀行體系在2024年維持穩健。金管局迅速採取措施支援本地中小型企業，並透過風險為本監管與應變規劃保障銀行體系穩定，另又提供監管指引及支持業界應對新生風險，以提升銀行業的運作穩健性與網絡防衛韌性。為鼓勵應用金融科技，金管局推出連串跨行業項目，包括生成式人工智能「沙盒」。

金管局推出《保障消費者防詐騙約章2.0》，以加強銀行消費者保障。我們又推出「智安存」協助存款人有效保護存款，以及有關銀行無抵押消費信貸產品的冷靜期以減低衝動及過度借貸的風險。此外，金管局向銀行提供有關在面向客戶的服務中應用生成式人工智能的指引，又就二手物業買賣交易提供多一種支付安排與業界緊密合作。金管局亦透過發出數碼資產相關活動的指引、優化「跨境理財通」業務試點，以及簡化銷售投資及保險產品程序，提升客戶體驗，並同時確保投資者保障。年內完成個人信貸資料服務全面過渡至「信資通」。

金管局在香港的打擊洗錢及恐怖分子資金籌集制度方面扮演重要角色。透過提高經由反訛騙及洗黑錢情報工作組交換情報的速度及數量，與2023年相比，情報主導的可疑交易報告增加303%，促使凍結或充公的犯罪得益增加34%。有關促進銀行分享訊息以協助偵測及防止金融罪行的法例修訂的諮詢得到廣泛支持。金管局在4月根據交易監察系統專題審查結果提供指引，以及在9月推出計劃促進業界應用人工智能監察可疑活動。金管局亦與銀行業及香港警務處合作，優化「可疑帳號警示」機制及加強宣傳工作，並就防範、偵測及制止授權支付詐騙向銀行發出指引。

香港在實施包括資本充足及披露等國際監管標準方面取得良好進展。香港存款保障委員會優化了存款保障計劃的多個範疇，以加強對存款人的保障。

為確保處置機制具公信力，金管局實施處置標準，規定銀行須更新與對手方的金融合約，減低處置中的提前終止風險。此外，金管局在制定銀行的首選處置策略、應對處置可行性障礙以確保有足夠財政資源及處置中的運作持續性，以及提升處置執行能力方面均取得顯著進展。

# 目標

金管局的目標之一是促進銀行體系的安全及穩定。要達致這個目標，實有賴建立及維持具高度應對能力且能為香港經濟提供所需關鍵金融服務的金融體系。

銀行可能因其營運方式，甚或在極端情況下因失序地倒閉而影響金融體系的穩定。作為監管當局，金融管理專員在保障金融穩定方面擔當重要角色，確保銀行有能力抵禦衝擊及應對危機，以最終有助防止出現倒閉。金融管理專員負責對銀行進行審慎監管，以及認可香港的持牌銀行、有限制牌照銀行及接受存款公司（統稱「認可機構」）。

香港的審慎監管制度並非為確保「零風險」而設。事實上，作為一個處置機制當局，金融管理專員力求確保一旦有認可機構不再可持續經營，能有秩序地處理其倒閉。為此，香港已設立金融機構處置機制，金融管理專員在該機制下為認可機構的處置機制當局。為落實香港的處置機制，我們有必要制定處置規則及政策標準、進行處置規劃以排除認可機構處置可行性的障礙，以及建立金管局處置瀕臨倒閉認可機構的運作能力。為有效執行上述工作，金管局採納與國際一致及協調的方法。

金融管理專員亦負責指定及監察某些金融市場基建。金管局監察金融市場基建的目的，是促進有關基建的整體安全及效率、減低系統性風險，以及提高透明度。提升金融市場基建面對金融危機的抗震能力，能保障香港的貨幣與金融體系，避免因金融市場基建運作中斷而影響其穩定。

# 2024年回顧

# 牌照事宜

年內金管局向一間在香港成立為法團的銀行及一間在香港以外成立為法團的銀行授予銀行牌照。金管局亦核准一間在香港以外的交易商經紀成為貨幣經紀。此外，年內金管局撤銷三間持牌銀行、一間有限制牌照銀行及一間接受存款公司的認可資格。

有關香港的認可機構及本地代表辦事處的更多資訊，請參閱分別載於第311至314頁及第320至323頁的附錄及表D至F。

# 檢討銀行三級制

在2024年，金管局完成有關簡化銀行三級制至二級制的公眾諮詢，回應者普遍支持簡化建議。經考慮所收到的意見，金管局就建議提出若干新的關鍵事項，以精簡過渡過程及減少對接受存款公司現有客戶的影響。

# 「虛擬銀行」易名

此外，金管局完成有關「虛擬銀行(Virtual Bank)」易名為「數字銀行(Digital Bank)」的公眾諮詢。易名建議得到廣泛支持，金管局遂於10月修訂法定指引《數字銀行的認可》，有關建議正式生效。

# 數字銀行的檢討

在2024年完成的另一項工作是全面檢討數字銀行，檢討報告已於8月發表。有關檢討顯示數字銀行發展至今已達到在香港引入數字銀行的三項政策目標，即推動金融科技與創新、提供新的客戶體驗，以及促進普及金融。在數字銀行和傳統銀行的多樣化發展下，金管局認為現時數字銀行牌照的數量合適，現階段沒有必要在市場上引入更多新的數字銀行參與者。10月發出的修訂指引《數字銀行的認可》放寬了數項對業界的限制，包括容許數字銀行經營零售銀行業務以外的銀行業務，以及在從客戶體驗與業務策略的角度而言屬合理的情況下設立實體分行，前提是數字銀行繼續主要透過數碼渠道提供銀行服務。

# 銀行牌照費的檢討

金管局於年內完成對牌照費的檢討，並於6月提高費用水平。

# 香港的公司遷冊制度

金管局就於香港引入公司遷冊制度向政府提供支援，包括協助修訂《銀行業條例》及其附屬法例以及其他與金管局有關的法例的立法程序。

# 監管工作概覽

年內金管局共進行174次非現場審查，涵蓋範圍甚廣，包括認可機構的CAMEL評估、企業管治及風險管理。為繼續加強認可機構的風險管治水平，金管局與認可機構董事局、獨立非執行董事或董事局轄下委員會共舉行36次會議，並與認可機構及其外聘核數師共舉行38次三方聯席會議。此外，金管局對認可機構的各項業務進行現場審查，包括信用、市場及流動性風險管理方面的管治與做法。

鑑於認可機構應用科技的情況越趨普及，業務操作風險及科技風險管理是另一個監管重點。金管局亦進一步加強對認可機構氣候風險管理的監管，以提高認可機構應對氣候變化的能力。金管局在全球經濟不明朗的環境下維持金融穩定及促進經濟穩健增長等方面的工作得到肯定，獲《亞洲銀行家》雜誌(The AsianBanker)評選為「亞太區最佳宏觀經濟監管機構」(BestMacroeconomic Regulator in Asia Pacific)。

# banking sector stability

Despite facing macroeconomic challenges and geopolitical uncertainties, Hong Kong’s banking sector maintained stability in 2024. The HKMA swiftly took measures to support local small and medium-sized enterprises, and through risk-based supervision and contingency planning, provided protection for the banking sector’s stability. It also provided supervisory guidelines and support for the industry to respond to new risks, to enhance the robustness and network defense resilience of the banking sector. To encourage the application of financial technology, the HKMA launched a series of cross-sectoral projects, including a Generative Artificial Intelligence Sandbox.

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority has launched the "Protection of Consumers from Scams Charter 2.0" to enhance consumer protection in banks. We have also launched "SmartSafe Deposit" to assist depositors in effectively protecting their deposits, and guidance related to banks’ unsecured consumer credit products’ cooling-off period to mitigate impulsive and excessive borrowing risks. Furthermore, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority provides banks with guidance on applying Generative Artificial Intelligence in customer-facing services, and offers more payment arrangements for secondary property transactions, working closely with the industry. The Hong Kong Monetary Authority also provides guidance on cross-boundary digital asset activities, optimizes the Pilot Scheme for Wealth Management Connect, and streamlines procedures for selling investment and insurance products, enhancing customer experience and ensuring investor protection. Personal credit reference services have been fully transitioned to “Credit Reference Connect” within the year.

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority plays an important role in Hong Kong’s Anti-Money Laundering and combating the financing of terrorism regime. Through increasing the volume and speed of information exchanged via the Joint Financial Intelligence Unit, suspicious transaction reporting led by intelligence has increased by 303% compared to 2023, prompting an increase of 34% in criminal proceeds frozen or confiscated. The consultation on legislative changes to promote banks’ sharing of information to assist in detecting and preventing financial crime has received broad support. In April, the HKMA provided guidance based on the thematic review of the transaction monitoring system, and in September launched a Scheme to promote the industry’s application of Artificial Intelligence to monitor suspicious activity. The HKMA also collaborates with the banking sector and the Hong Kong Police Force to optimise the “suspicious account alert” mechanism and strengthen promotional work, and provides guidance to banks on preventing, detecting, and disrupting authorised payment scams.

Hong Kong has made good progress in implementing international supervisory standards including capital adequacy and disclosure etc. Hong Kong’s Deposit Protection Committee has enhanced various areas of the Deposit Protection Scheme to strengthen protection for depositors.

To ensure a credible resolution mechanism with credibility, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority implements resolution standards, require banks to update their financial contracts with counterparties, and reduce early termination risks during resolution. Furthermore, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority has made significant progress in determining banks’ preferred resolution strategies, combatting barriers to resolution resolvability to ensure adequate financial resources and continued operational continuity during resolution, and enhancing execution capabilities.

# objective

The HKMA’s objective is to promote the stability and maintain the soundness of the banking sector. To achieve this objective, it relies on establishing and maintaining a financial system with a high degree of resilience that can respond to demand and provide critical financial services for Hong Kong’s economy.

Banks may be impacted by their operational methods, or even in extreme situations due to disorderly failure, affecting the stability of the financial system. As the supervisory authority, Monetary Authority plays an important role in ensuring financial stability, ensuring banks have the resilience to withstand shocks and respond to crises, to ultimately help prevent failure. The Monetary Authority is responsible for prudential supervision of banks, and authorization of licensed banks, banks with a limit on their license, and Deposit taking companies (collectively named “authorized institutions”).

Hong Kong’s prudential supervisory system is not designed to ensure “zero risk”. In fact, as a resolution mechanism authority, the Monetary Authority seeks to ensure that once an authorized institution is no longer viable, its failure can be handled in an orderly resolution. To this end, Hong Kong has established a financial institution resolution mechanism, under which the Monetary Authority serves as the resolution mechanism authority for authorized institutions. To implement Hong Kong’s resolution mechanism, it is necessary to develop a set of rules and policy standards, conduct resolution planning to eliminate barriers to the resolvability of authorized institutions, and build the operational capacity of the Monetary Authority to dispose of authorized institutions nearing failure. To effectively carry out the above work, the Monetary Authority adopts methods that are consistent with and coordinate international supervisory efforts.

The Monetary Authority also has responsibility for specified and monitoring certain financial market infrastructure. The primary purpose of HKMA’s monitoring of financial market infrastructure is to promote the overall safety and efficiency of related infrastructure, reduce systemic risks, and enhance transparency. Enhancing the resilience of financial market infrastructure to financial crises can protect Hong Kong’s currency and financial system, and avoid impacting its stability due to disruptions in the operations of market infrastructure.

# 2024 return

# Licensing matters

During the year, the HKMA granted bank licenses to a bank established as a corporation in Hong Kong and a bank established outside of Hong Kong as a corporation. The HKMA also approved an external transaction broker to become a monetary broker. In addition, during the year, the HKMA revoked the authorization of three licensed banks, a bank with a limit license, and a Deposit taking company.

# Reviews of the banking sector’s three-level system

In 2024, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority completed the public consultation related to streamlining the banking three-tier system to a two-tier system, and respondents generally support the recommendations. After considering the advice received, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority has issued several new key issues to streamline the transition process and reduce the impact on existing customers of deposit-taking companies.

# “Virtual bank” rebrands.

此外，金管局 complete related “Virtual Bank” to “Digital Bank” Public consultation. The proposal support was widespread, and the 金管局 subsequently revised the statutory guidance 《認可數字銀行》 in October. The recommendations are officially effective.

# Digital banking reviews

In another work completed in 2024, a comprehensive review of digital banks was conducted, and the review report was published in August. The review shows that the development of digital banks has already achieved the three policy objectives for introducing digital banks in Hong Kong, namely promote innovation and financial technology, provide new customer experience, and promote widespread finance. Under the diversified development of digital banks and traditional banks, the HKMA believes that the current volume of digital bank licenses is appropriate and that it is not necessary at this stage to introduce more new digital bank participants into the market. Amendments to the guidelines "Authorization of Digital Banks" issued in October relax several restrictions on the industry, including allowing digital banks to operate banking business beyond retail banking, and establishing physical branches where the situation is reasonable from the perspective of customer experience and business strategy, provided that digital banks continue to primarily provide banking services through digital channels.

# Review of bank license fees.

The Financial Supervisory Commission completed a review of licensing costs within the year and raised the fee level in June.

# Hong Kong’s company migration system

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority provides support to the Government regarding the introduction of company migration arrangements in Hong Kong, including assisting with legislative changes to the banking sector’s legislation and related legislation, as well as the legislative procedures related to the Hong Kong Monetary Authority.

# Supervisory Overview

Within the year, the Monetary Authority conducted 174 off-site due diligence reviews, covering a wide scope, including assessment of authorized institutions’ CAMEL, corporate governance, and risk management. To continue to promote the risk governance level of authorized institutions, the Monetary Authority, together with the boards of directors of authorized institutions, independent non-executive directors or committees under the boards, co-chaired 36 meetings. Furthermore, the Monetary Authority, in co-operation with authorized institutions and their external auditors, held 38 three-party co-chaired meetings. In addition, the Monetary Authority conducted on-site examination of various business tasks of authorized institutions, including governance and practices in credit, market, and liquidity risk management.

Given the increasing prevalence of technology applications by authorized institutions, risk management of business operations and technology risks is another key regulatory focus. The HKMA has also further strengthened its supervision of climate risk management by authorized institutions to enhance their resilience to climate changing. The HKMA’s work in maintaining financial stability and promote robust growth in the global economic environment has been commended, and it was selected by The AsianBanker as “Best Macroeconomic Regulator in Asia Pacific”.

Assistant Chief Executive (Banking Supervision) Ms. Chloe Chu, on behalf of the Hong Kong Monetary Authority, received the “Asia Pacific Region Best Macroeconomic Supervision Institution” award presented by The Asian Banker.

In supervisory regulation, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority conducts on-site examination of securities, investment products, trusts, insurance and Mandatory Provident Fund (MPF) related business of authorized institutions, as well as consumer protection matters, and uses thematic assessment as a means to ensure, to review new projects or areas assessed as high risk.

# 香港的國際金融中心地位

金管局於2024年在加強香港作為具全球競爭力的國際金融中心的地位方面取得重要進展。

金管局與內地及香港有關當局合作，推出一系列措施，共同深化及擴展香港與內地金融市場的互聯互通，包括優化「粵港澳大灣區跨境理財通」；擴大金管局人民幣流動資金安排及「北向互換通」的合資格抵押品範圍；優化「北向互換通」；以及優化一級流動性提供行安排。這些措施有助強化香港的門戶角色，並鞏固其作為全球離岸人民幣業務樞紐的地位

金管局在鞏固香港金融平台的競爭力方面亦取得良好進展，涵蓋債券發行、資產及財富管理、綠色和可持續金融，以及企業財資中心等範疇。為宣傳香港的金融服務，金管局加強面向海外及內地持份者的市場推廣工作，讓大家充分認識香港金融體系的穩健及其帶來的機遇。第三屆「國際金融領袖投資峰會」及多項其他盛事成功舉辦，不僅有助提升香港作為主要國際金融中心的形象，更製造正面的漣漪效應。金管局積極參與多個國際及區內的央行及監管組織，繼續對維持金融穩定及促進金融市場發展的全球工作作出貢獻。

金管局在「金融科技2025」 策略的各個範疇均取得顯著進展，包括央行數碼貨幣及數據基建。

快速支付系統「轉數快」的登記數目及交易量繼續穩步增長，於2024年底達到1,580萬個登記，全年平均每日處理港元即時交易增至165萬宗。金管局正與中國人民銀行緊密合作，推動落實香港「轉數快」與內地網上支付跨行清算系統互聯，實現跨境支付。

# 概覽

在2024年，金管局繼續致力提升香港作為國際金融中心的競爭力。

金管局擴展及優化香港與內地間的互聯互通機制，有助鞏固香港作為內地與國際金融市場間的橋樑角色。年內，多項有關「粵港澳大灣區跨境理財通」（「跨境理財通」）的優化措施出台，便利粵港澳大灣區（大灣區）個人投資者進行跨境投資。於2月，金管局將中華人民共和國財政部（國家財政部）發行的在岸國債和內地政策性銀行發行的政策性金融債納入人民幣流動資金安排的合資格抵押品名單。於7月，兩地相關部門公布進一步支持境外投資者使用通過「債券通」持有的在岸債券作為「北向互換通」交易的履約抵押品，並於2025年1月實施。此外，「北向互換通」於年內進行優化，增加投資者在對沖策略和管理投資組合方面的靈活性及效率。

在2024年，香港的離岸人民幣業務穩健增長。金管局推出一級流動性提供行安排的優化措施，包括增加提供行數目及擴大安排規模。於年底前，香港人民幣即時支付結算系統的夜間跨境服務能力提升，以更好應付全球各地對跨境人民幣支付的需要。

金管局推出大灣區金融合作下的多項利民便商措施，包括促進企業跨境融資的跨境徵信互通業務試點，以及便利香港居民在大灣區置業的跨境匯款支付安排。

金管局繼續致力提升香港整體金融平台的競爭力。具體而言，為增強香港作為首選基金管理中心及家族辦公室業務樞紐的吸引力，金管局與政府及金融業緊密合作，締造更便利的稅務及監管環境。此外，金管局透過Evergreen項目發行第二批代幣化債券，並推出「EvergreenHub」一站式數碼債券知識庫和「數碼債券資助計劃」，繼續推動香港債券市場創新。於10月，金管局公布「可持續金融行動計劃」，訂明進一步鞏固香港作為區內綠色和可持續金融樞紐的具體目標。

另一方面，金管局繼續加強市場拓展工作，向海外及內地持份者介紹香港的金融服務。金管局在11月舉辦第三屆「國際金融領袖投資峰會」。峰會為期三日，主題為「在變局中前航」，雲集全球各地金融業界翹楚分享各自獨到的觀點。峰會先由國務院副總理何立峰先生作開幕主題演講，接着是三間內地金融監管機構的分享環節，以及由國際金融領袖參與的專題討論。峰會共匯聚350多位來自超過120間國際金融機構的領袖參與，充分體現國際金融界對香港的支持和信心。

年內金管局亦舉辦各項其他研討會及會議，包括：

- 於9月與迪拜金融服務管理局合辦聯合氣候金融會議；
- 於10月與全球風險管理專業人士協會合辦第15屆全球風險論壇；
- 於10月亦與國際結算銀行合辦國際金融研討會；及
- 於12月舉辦金融穩定理事會全體會議，是自2016年以來首次在亞洲舉行的同類會議，匯聚超過50個國家財政金融機關及12個國際標準制定機構的領袖和高級官員。

年內金管局亦積極加強與其他地區的雙邊聯繫。於12月，金管局分別與阿拉伯聯合酋長國中央銀行（阿聯酋央行）及沙特中央銀行（沙特央行）在香港舉行雙邊會議，促進中東與亞洲地區之間的投資及金融市場聯繫。金管局與阿聯酋央行簽署諒解備忘錄，建立兩地債務資本市場基建的互聯互通，並促進跨境債務證券發行及投資活動。在此之前，金管局於10月訪問卡塔爾多哈，加強兩地金融服務領域的合作。

此外，金管局於12月舉行第七次香港與瑞士金融合作對話，討論內容涵蓋區內及本地的前景與政策挑戰，以及可持續金融、金融科技與市場互聯互通領域的最新發展及潛在合作空間。

金管局分別於1月及5月訪問泰國和馬來西亞，與中央銀行、金融機構和企業會面，推廣香港作為國際金融中心的地位，並進一步加強雙邊金融聯繫和合作。重點領域之一是推廣使用人民幣和本地貨幣作跨境投資和貿易結算，以及香港的競爭優勢。

在國際層面，金管局積極參與中央銀行領域的事務，並繼續在多個區內及國際委員會擔當領導角色。金管局現為巴塞爾銀行監管委員會（巴塞爾委員會）轄下政策及標準小組和金融穩定理事會轄下亞洲區域諮詢小組的聯席主席，另又擔任金融穩定理事會轄下金融創新網絡聯席主席（至2024年7月止）。金管局亦為國際結算銀行轄下主要新興市場經濟體行長會議和金融穩定理事會轄下加密資產框架同業評審小組的主席。在2018至2024年間，金管局一直連任東亞及太平洋地區中央銀行會議(EMEAP)轄下金融市場工作小組主席。

金管局金融科技促進辦公室與各銀行部門繼續實施「金融科技2025」策略，促進業界廣泛採用金融科技，並提升香港作為亞洲金融科技樞紐的地位。年內推行的主要措施包括：

- 進一步推動銀行在五個主要範疇的金融科技應用，包括財富科技、保險科技、綠色科技、人工智能及分布式分類帳技術；
- 推動央行數碼貨幣的工作，以了解其效益及潛在的應用場景，包括：
    - 推進「多種央行數碼貨幣跨境網絡」(mBridge)項目，以改善跨境支付；
    - 進一步研究在香港發行「數碼港元」(e-HKD)的可行性；及
    - 開始探索以央行數碼貨幣支持香港代幣化市場的發展；
- 透過「商業數據通」便利中小企借貸；
- 加強跨境金融科技合作；及
- 推動更廣泛使用快速支付系統「轉數快」。

「轉數快」的使用在2024年繼續增加，登記數目與交易量在過去六年穩步上升。截至2024年底，「轉數快」登記數目增至1,580萬個，全年每日平均交易宗數較上年上升33%。除個人對個人支付及商業支付穩步增長外，透過「轉數快」繳付政府帳單、支付予商戶及為儲值支付工具電子錢包或銀行帳戶增值持續增加，是帶動「轉數快」交易量持續增長的主要原因。

為確保本地零售支付業的安全及效率，金管局根據《支付系統及儲值支付工具條例》（《支付條例》）監察六個指定零售支付系統，並監管15項持牌儲值支付工具（其中四項由持牌銀行發行）。年內金管局繼續與業界緊密合作，因應詐騙風險上升加強管控措施及保障消費者。

財經事務及庫務局與金管局就在香港實施穩定幣發行人監管制度的立法建議，於2月完成為期兩個月的公眾諮詢後，於7月聯合發表諮詢總結，並於12月將《穩定幣條例草案》提交立法會審議。為更了解穩定幣發行人的業務模式，並制定適切的監管制度，金管局亦推出穩定幣發行人「沙盒」，並於7月公布三間進入「沙盒」的參與機構。與此同時，金管局繼續積極參與國際組織在數碼資產相關課題（包括穩定幣及代幣化）的工作，確保相關監管框架符合國際標準及最佳做法。

# Hong Kong’s international financial centre status

The HKMA has made important progress in 2024 in strengthening Hong Kong’s status as a global competitive Financial Centre.

The HKMA is collaborating with Mainland and Hong Kong authorities to launch a range of measures, together deepening and expanding the linkage and connectivity of Hong Kong’s and Mainland’s financial markets, including enhancements to the “Guangdong-Hong Kong-Macao Greater Bay Area Cross-boundary Wealth Management Connect”; expanding the eligible collateral scope of the HKMA’s RMB Liquidity Facility and Northbound Bond Connect; optimising Northbound Bond Connect; and optimising the Primary liquidity providing arrangement. These measures help reinforce Hong Kong’s gateway role and underpin its status as a hub for offshore renminbi business.

The HKMA has also made good progress in bolstering Hong Kong’s competitiveness as a financial platform, covering areas such as bond issuance, asset and wealth management, green and sustainable finance, and corporate treasury centres. To promote Hong Kong’s financial services, the HKMA has strengthened market outreach efforts targeted at stakeholders and the Mainland, allowing everyone to fully understand the soundness of Hong Kong’s financial system and the opportunities it brings. The third Investment Summit and various other successful events have not only helped enhance Hong Kong’s image as a leading international financial centre, but also created a positive ripple effect. The HKMA actively participates in various international and regional central banks and supervisory organisations, continuing to contribute to the global work of maintaining financial stability and promote development of the financial markets.

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority has made significant progress in all areas of the "Fintech 25" strategy, including central bank digital currency and data infrastructure.

The Faster Payment System “FPS” registration numbers and turnover continue to grow steadily, reaching 15.8 million registrations at the end of 2024. The whole year average daily processing of Hong Kong dollar real-time transactions increased to 1.65 million items. HKMA is working closely with the People’s Bank of China to promote the implementation of linkage between Hong Kong’s “FPS” and Mainland online payment bank-to-bank clearing system, realizing cross-border payment.

# Overview

In 2024, the HKMA continues strives to enhance Hong Kong’s competitiveness as an international financial centre.

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority has expanded and optimised the mutual connectivity mechanism between Hong Kong and the Mainland, which supports Hong Kong’s role as a bridge between the Mainland and international financial markets. Several enhancements related to the “Guangdong-Hong Kong-Macao Greater Bay Area Wealth Management Connect” (“WMC”) were implemented this year, facilitating cross-border investment by individual investors in the Greater Bay Area (GBA). In February, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority added onshore government bonds issued by the Ministry of Finance of the People’s Republic of China (National Treasury) and policy financial bonds issued by Mainland policy banks to the list of eligible collateral for the RMB Liquidity Facility. In July, relevant departments in the two jurisdictions announced further support for offshore investors to use onshore bonds held through the “Bond Connect” as collateral for “Northbound Bond Connect” transactions, to be implemented in January 2025. Furthermore, the “Northbound Bond Connect” underwent optimisation this year, increasing the agility and efficiency of investors in hedging strategies and managing investment portfolios.

In 2024, Hong Kong’s offshore renminbi business grew robustly. The HKMA launched enhancements to the Primary liquidity providing arrangement, including increase in the number of providing banks and expanding the arrangement scale. By the end of the year, the night-time cross-border Real-Time Gross Settlement services capability of Hong Kong’s Renminbi Payment system will enhance to better payable global demand for cross-border renminbi payments.

The HKMA launched a number of facilitative measures under financial co-operation in the Greater Bay Area, including a pilot scheme to promote cross-border financing through cross-boundary credit information sharing business, and arrangements to facilitate payments for Hong Kong residents’ cross-boundary property purchases.

The HKMA continues strives to enhance Hong Kong’s overall financial platform’s competitiveness. Specifically, to promote Hong Kong as a preferred Management Centre and a hub for family business, the HKMA collaborates closely with the Government and the financial sector to create a more facilitated tax and supervisory environment. Furthermore, through the Evergreen project, the HKMA issued the second batch of tokenized bonds and launched the “EvergreenHub” one-stop digital bond knowledge repository and the “Digital Bond Grant Scheme”, continuing to promote innovation in Hong Kong’s bond market. In October, the HKMA announced the “Sustainable Finance Action Plan”, provides specific objectives to further consolidate Hong Kong as a regional green and sustainable finance hub.

On the other hand, Hong Kong’s supervisory work continues to expand market拓展工作, to promote Hong Kong’s financial services to overseas and the Mainland stakeholders. The HKMA held the third Investment Summit in November. The summit lasts three days, with the theme "Navigating Change," bringing together industry leaders from around the world to share their unique perspectives. The summit began with an opening keynote speech by Deputy Premier He Lifeng, followed by a sharing session from three Mainland financial regulatory institutions, and a special discussion participated in by international financial leaders. The summit共匯聚350多位來自超過120間國際金融機構的participants, fully demonstrated the financial community’s support and confidence in Hong Kong.

Within the year, the Financial Supervisory Commission also hold various other workshops and meetings, including:

- Co-host a joint climate finance meeting with the Dubai Financial Services Authority in September;
- Co-organise the 15th Global Risk Forum with the Asia professional risk management personnel association in October;
- Also in October, co-host an international financial seminar with the Bank for International Clearing; and
- Hold a meeting of the Financial Stability Board in December, which will be the first event of its kind in Asia since 2016, bringing together leaders and senior officials from more than 50 countries’ financial institutions and 12 international standards organisations.

Within the year, the HKMA also actively strengthened bilateral linkages with other regions. In December, the HKMA held bilateral meetings in Hong Kong with the Central Bank of the United Arab Emirates (UAE Central Bank) and the Central Bank of Saudi Arabia (Saudi Central Bank), promoteing linkages between the Middle East and Asia regions' investment and financial markets. The HKMA signed a Memorandum of Understanding with the UAE Central Bank to establish cross-border debt capital market infrastructure linkage and promote cross-border debt securities issuance and investment activities. Prior to this, in October, the HKMA visited Doha, Qatar, to strengthen cooperation in the areas of financial services.

In the international domain, the Monetary Authority actively participates in affairs within the central banking sector and continues to play a leadership role in various regional and international committees. The Hong Kong Monetary Authority’s Fintech Facilitation Office and various bank departments continue implementing the “Fintech 2025” strategy, promote the widespread adoption of fintech within the industry, and enhance Hong Kong’s status as an Asian fintech hub. # 儲備管理

2024年環球金融市場表現大致良好。主要經濟體錄得穩定增長，而通脹亦回落至更接近政策目標的水平。多個主要央行陸續下調政策利率，有利投資環境。2024年全年計，外匯基金錄得2,188億港元的投資收入，投資回報率為5.2%。

# 外匯基金

根據《外匯基金條例》，外匯基金的首要目的是直接或間接影響港元匯價，亦可運用於保持香港貨幣及金融體系穩定健全，藉此保持香港作為國際金融中心的地位。金管局根據財政司司長轉授的權力及轉授權力的條款，就外匯基金的運用及投資管理向財政司司長負責。

# 外匯基金的管理

# 投資目標及組合架構

外匯基金諮詢委員會為外匯基金制定下列投資目標：

(i) 保障資本；
(ii) 確保整體貨幣基礎在任何時候都由流通性極高的美元資產提供十足支持；
(iii) 確保流動資金足以維持貨幣及金融穩定；以及
(iv) 在符合上述(i)至(iii)項的前提下盡量爭取投資回報，以保障外匯基金的長期購買力。

以上目標全面顧及外匯基金的法定目的，並已於外匯基金的組合架構及目標資產配置中反映（圖示1）。

圖示1 外匯基金的投資組合類別

外匯基金大致上分成兩個主要組合：支持組合及投資組合。支持組合持有流通性極高的美元資產，按照貨幣發行局制度的規定為貨幣基礎提供十足支持。投資組合主要投資於經濟合作與發展組織成員經濟體的債市及股市，以保障資產的價值及長期購買力。

為能更妥善管理風險及提高中長期回報，金管局以審慎及循序漸進方式將外匯基金的部分資產配置於較多元化的資產類別，包括新興巿場及內地債券與股票、私募股權（包括基建）及房地產。新興巿場及內地債券與股票由投資組合持有，私募股權及房地產投資則由長期增長組合持有。長期增長組合的目標資產配置與其他資產類別的配置，按審慎的風險管理原則及資產組合多元化策略一起制定。

策略性資產組合於2007年設立，一直持有政府基於策略性目的而為外匯基金帳目購入的香港交易及結算所有限公司股份。由於這個組合性質獨特，因此外匯基金的投資表現評估並無將其包括在內。

# 於外匯基金的存款

外匯基金不時接受財政儲備、政府基金及法定組織的存款，利率一般與投資組合的表現掛鈎，但未來基金屬主要個別例子，其存款的利率與投資組合及長期增長組合的回報掛鈎，利率視乎實際資產配置而定。於2024年，投資組合與長期增長組合在未來基金的目標資產配置約為35：65。

# 投資程序

外匯基金的投資程序分別以策略性資產配置及戰略性資產配置作基礎。策略性資產配置以投資基準方式反映，亦即外匯基金為達到投資目標而可作出的長線資產配置。外匯基金以策略性配置作為指引，透過戰略性的資產配置，以爭取超越基準的回報。因此，實際配置往往會與基準配置（亦即策略性配置）有所偏離，而實際與基準配置之間的差距稱為「戰略性偏離」。財政司司長經諮詢外匯基金諮詢委員會後制定投資基準及循跡誤差限額，金管局獲授權決定戰略性資產配置及定出戰略性偏離的容許範圍。投資組合經理可在戰略性偏離的容許範圍內管理倉盤，從短期市場變化中獲利。

# 直接投資

金管局的外匯基金投資辦公室專責外匯基金的投資及相關風險管理職能。該辦公室職員負責直接管理外匯基金約70%的投資，包括整個支持組合及部分投資組合。該部分內部管理的投資組合包括環球定息市場投資，並透過不同的衍生工具執行外匯基金的宏觀風險管理策略。

# 外聘投資經理

除透過內部職員管理資產外，金管局亦僱用外聘投資經理負責管理外匯基金約30%的資產，包括所有上市股票組合及其他特別資產類別。僱用外聘投資經理的目的是要運用市場上最佳的專業投資專才為外匯基金投資，獲取可持續回報，並讓外匯基金受惠於多元化及互補的投資方式，以及汲取外聘投資經理的市場心得與專門的投資知識。

僱用外聘投資經理的相關支出包括基金管理與託管費、交易費、預扣稅及其他稅項。這些支出主要受市場因素影響而每年不同。

# 風險管理及監察

投資環境越趨複雜，穩健的風險管理更見重要。金管局為內部及外聘投資經理所管理的投資組合均訂下嚴格管控措施及投資指引，並設立嚴謹的風險監察及合規制度。金管局為投資相關活動設有三重防線，以實施有效的風險管理及管治。金管局定期監察主要投資風險類別（包括信用、市場、流動性及業務操作風險），並設置風險管理程序，為策略性規劃及多元化投資工作提供穩健的框架。

# 負責任投資

金管局相信適度強調負責任投資及投資的可持續長期表現，可更有效達致外匯基金的投資目標，並且減低投資活動涉及的環境、社會及管治(ESG)相關風險。為積極支持負責任投資，金管局已將ESG因素融入外匯基金的投資管理過程中，其指導性原則是：當ESG投資與其他投資項目的經風險調整長期收益相若時，一般會優先考慮ESG投資。有關金管局在負責任投資方面的工作，詳見《二零二四年可持續發展報告》之「負責任投資」一章。

# 外匯基金的表現

# 2024年的金融市場

2024年環球金融市場表現大致良好。

主要股票市場於2024年升幅顯著，當中美國股市在經濟和通脹基調大致向好和人工智能熱潮背景下，首三季升幅尤其突出。不過第4季市況因憂慮通脹升溫及債息上升等而變得波動並從高位回落，投資者亦轉趨審慎。內地和香港股市方面，受惠於中央在第3季出台的一系列刺激經濟和股市的政策措施，投資者信心有所好轉。然而市場認為實體經濟增長依然不明朗的情況下，兩地股市於第4季回軟。

環球債券市場在2024年的表現亦有較大波動。儘管主要央行大致確立減息的大方向，但減息的節奏和幅度年內出現多次轉變。及至第4季，市場開始注視美國2025年的財政政策，美國國債收益率季內大幅上升，債價受壓。

貨幣市場方面，美元兌其他主要貨幣於2024年，特別是第4季，因為息口走勢和美國經濟表現相對強勁而走強。

於2024年底，外匯基金的資產總值達40,810億港元。長期增長組合投資的總市值為5,412億港元，其中私募股權為4,348億港元，房地產為1,064億港元。長期增長組合中已承擔但尚未提取作投資的總額為2,886億港元。

# Reserves management

2024 global financial markets performed broadly well. Major economies recorded stable growth, and inflation also retreated to a level more close to policy objectives. Several central banks successively lowered policy rates, which is beneficial to the investment environment. For the whole year of 2024, the Exchange Fund recorded investment income of HK$218.8 billion, with a rate of return of 5.2%.

# Exchange Fund

According to the Exchange Fund Ordinance, the primary purpose of the Exchange Fund is to directly or indirectly impact the exchange value of the Hong Kong dollar, and may also be used to maintain the stability and soundness of Hong Kong’s monetary and financial system(s), thereby maintaining Hong Kong’s status as a financial centre. The HKMA, responsible to the Financial Secretary under the delegations of powers and delegated powers provisions, manages the Exchange Fund’s investment and management and is responsible to the Financial Secretary.

# Foreign Exchange Fund management

# Investment objectives and portfolio structure

The Exchange Fund Advisory Committee is to formulate the following investment objectives for the Exchange Fund.

(i) Protect capital;
(ii) Ensure the overall monetary foundation is fully supported by US dollar assets with high liquidity;
(iii) Ensure liquidity capital is sufficient for maintaining currency and financial stability; and
(iv) Under the premise of meeting items (i) to (iii) above, strive for investment return as much as possible to protect the long-term purchasing power of the Exchange Fund.

The above objectives fully consider the statutory purpose of the Exchange Fund and have already been reflected in the Exchange Fund’s portfolio structure and target asset allocation (Mapping 1).

Chart 1 illustrates the Exchange Fund’s investment portfolio categories.

The Exchange Fund broadly consists of two main portfolios: support portfolios and investment portfolios. Support portfolios held highly liquid US dollar asset(s), providing fully support for the monetary basis as required by the currency issuing system. The investment portfolio primarily invests in bond markets and stock markets of economies of economic cooperation and development organisations members, to protect the value of asset(s) and long-term purchasing power.

To better manage risk and enhance long-term return, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority, in a prudent and incremental manner, has allocated a portion of the Exchange Fund's asset mix to a more diversified range of asset classes, including emerging markets and the Mainland bond and stock markets, private equity (including infrastructure) and real estate. Emerging markets and Mainland bonds and stocks are held by the investment Portfolio, while private equity and real estate investments are held by the long-term growth Portfolio. The target asset allocation of the long-term growth Portfolio, together with the allocation of other asset classes, is determined in accordance with prudent risk management principles and a diversified asset mix strategy.

A strategic asset portfolio was established in 2007, and has consistently held shares of Hong Kong Exchange Clearing Limited, purchased for Exchange Fund accounts with a strategic objective. Due to the unique nature of this portfolio, the assessment of the Exchange Fund’s investment performance does not include it.

# At the Exchange Fund deposit

The Exchange Fund occasionally accept deposits from fiscal Reserves, Government fund(s) and statutory organisations, with interest rates generally linked to the performance of the investment Portfolio. However, the Future Fund is a major individual example, and its deposit policy rates are linked to the return of the investment Portfolio and long-term growth asset mix. The rate of interest depends on the actual asset allocation. In 2024, the target asset allocation for the investment Portfolio and long-term growth Portfolio in the Future Fund was about 35:65.

# Investment procedures

The Exchange Fund’s investment procedures are based on strategic asset allocation and strategic asset allocation. Strategic asset allocation reflects an investment basis, that is, the long-term asset allocation that the Exchange Fund can make to achieve its investment objective. The Exchange Fund uses strategic allocation as guidance, and through strategic asset allocation, seeks to achieve returns exceeding the benchmark. Therefore, actual allocation will often deviate from the benchmark allocation (that is, strategic allocation), and the difference between actual and benchmark allocation is known as "strategic deviation." The Financial Secretary, after consultation with the Advisory Committees, determines the investment benchmark and sets the tracking error quota, and the Monetary Authority is authorized to decide on strategic asset allocation and set the allowable scope of strategic deviation. Portfolio managers can manage positions within the allowable scope of strategic deviation, and profit from changing short-dated markets.

# investment

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority’s Exchange Fund Investment Office is responsible for the investment and related risk management Functions of the Exchange Fund. Office staff are responsible for directly managing approximately 70% of the Exchange Fund's investments, including the entire support Portfolio and part of the investment portfolios. This internally managed Portfolio includes global fixed-income market investments, and through various derivative tools executes the Exchange Fund’s macro risk management strategy.

# External investment manager

除透過內部職員管理資產外，金管局亦僱用外聘投資經理負責管理外匯基金約30%的資產，包括所有上市股票組合及其他特別資產類別。僱用外聘投資經理的目的是要運用市場上最佳的專業投資專才為外匯基金投資，to effect sustainable return, and let the Exchange Fund benefit from diversification and complementary investment means, as well as to acquire external investment managers’ market insights and specialized investment knowledge.

Employing external investment managers’ related expenses include fund management, depository fees, transaction fees, withholding tax and other taxes. These expenses are mainly impacted by market factors and vary year by year.

# Risk Management and Oversight

The investment environment is increasingly complex, and robust risk management is more important. The Hong Kong Monetary Authority has established rigorous controls and investment guidelines for all investment portfolios managed by internal and external managers, and established rigorous risk monitoring and compliance systems. The Hong Kong Monetary Authority has three lines of defense to implement effective risk management and governance. The Hong Kong Monetary Authority regularly monitors major risk categories (including credit, market, liquidity, and business operations risks) and sets up risk management procedures, providing a resilient framework for strategic planning and diversified work.

# Responsible investment

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority believes that moderately emphasizing responsible investment and the sustainable long-term performance of investment can more effectively achieve the Exchange Fund’s investment objectives and reduce the environmental, social, and governance (ESG) related risks involving investment activities. To actively support responsible investment, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority has integrated ESG factors into the Exchange Fund’s investment management process, with its guiding principles being: when ESG investment has a risk-adjusted long-term return comparable to other investment projects, ESG investment will generally be prioritised. See chapter "Responsible Investment" in the "2024 Sustainable Development Report" for further information related to the Hong Kong Monetary Authority’s work in responsible investment.

# Exchange Fund performance

# 2024 financial market

In 2024, global financial markets generally performed well.

Major stock markets saw significant growth in 2024, with the US market in particular exhibiting exceptional growth in the first three quarters amid generally positive economic and inflation trends and the Artificial Intelligence trend. However, market conditions in the fourth quarter became volatile and retreated from high levels as concerns over increasing inflation and rising bond yields emerged, and investors also grew more prudent. Mainland and Hong Kong markets benefited from a range of economic and stock market policy measures implemented by the Central in the third quarter, leading to improved investor confidence. However, given the situation where growth in the real economy remains uncertain, both regions’ stock markets softened in the fourth quarter.

Global bond markets have also experienced significant volatility in 2024. Although central banks generally established the general policy direction of interest rate cuts, the pace and magnitude of the cuts changed multiple times during the year. By the 4th quarter, markets began to watch the US fiscal policy for 2025, and US bond yields surged by 23.5% within the quarter, putting downward pressure on bond prices.

In terms of monetary markets, the US dollar strengthened against other major currencies in 2024, particularly in the fourth quarter, as interest rate trends and the US economy’s performance were relatively strong.

Table 1 set out the performance of major currency, bond markets, and stock markets in 2024.

# Exchange Fund performance

The Exchange Fund recorded investment income of HK$2,188 billion in 2024, including:

Gains from bond investments totaled HK$135.9 billion;
Gains from stock investments totaled HK$90.9 billion (of which HK$21.8 billion came from stock investments in Hong Kong, and HK$69.1 billion came from investments in other stocks);
a decrease in the value of foreign assets in exchange rates of HK$35.6 billion; and
gains from other investments held by subsidiaries of the Exchange Fund investment holding company totaled HK$27.6 billion.

On the other hand, the strategic Portfolio records gains of 28 billion Hong Kong dollars.

機構職能部門支持金管局的運作，保持高透明度與問責性，並發揮卓越的效率及專業水準。為促進公眾對金管局的政策及工作的了解，金管局透過傳統及社交媒體、金管局網站、金管局資訊中心及其他渠道積極與整體社會及市場參與者保持聯繫。

# 機構網站

機構網站(www.hkma.gov.hk)提供73,000多頁英文版及繁簡字體中文版資料，方便公眾查閱金管局的最新資訊。網站亦載有根據《銀行業條例》第20條備存的「認可機構及本地代表辦事處紀錄冊」及「認可機構證券業務員工紀錄冊」，以及根據《支付系統及儲值支付工具條例》備存的「儲值支付工具持牌人紀錄冊」。

金管局自2018年起透過開放應用程式介面（開放API），分階段發放在其網站所載的金融數據及重要資訊。截至2024年底，我們按照原定計劃在網站推出合共177組開放API。有關金管局開放API的更詳盡資料，請瀏覽金管局開放API門戶網站(https://apidocs.hkma.gov.hk)。

年內資訊中心接待超過68,000名訪客，較2023年增加約120%。資訊中心亦為學校及其他團體提供570多次導賞服務。

毗鄰展覽館的圖書館收藏超過26,000冊書籍、期刊及其他刊物，涵蓋香港貨幣、銀行業、金融和中央銀行事務等課題。圖書館亦備存《銀行業條例》第20條規定的「認可機構及本地代表辦事處紀錄冊」及「認可機構證券業務員工紀錄冊」，供公眾查閱。

參與「少年金融人才計劃」的學生與導師會面

在開發《$mart理財321》桌遊的經驗基礎上，金管局推出策略桌遊《企業綠化大變身》，於「香港書展2024」的攤位作為紀念品送出。這是全港首副向學生傳遞綠色金融知識的桌遊。

此外，我們繼續支持投資者及理財教育委員會的工作，提升香港市民的金融知識及理財能力，並會研究與不同持份者進一步合作，提高社區參與工作的成效。

# corporate functions

Institutions, departments, and business units support the operations of the Hong Kong Monetary Authority, maintaining high transparency and accountability, and unlock its excellent efficiency and professional professionalism. To promote public understanding of the Hong Kong Monetary Authority’s policies and work, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority actively maintains links with overall society and market participants through traditional and social media, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority website, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority Information Centre, and other channels.

Internally, the Monetary Authority strives to build a workforce that is agile, responsive, and professional, while maintaining strict financial discipline and enhancing digital capabilities, to respond to changing circumstances and ensure the effective implementation of various policies and measures.

# Maintain transparency.

# Media relations and social media application

The Monetary Authority maintains closely linked operations with media to enhance transparency and improve public understanding of its policies and operations. In 2024, the Monetary Authority held or participated in a total of 207 activities, including 14 press conferences, four media briefing sessions, 14 interviews, and 175 other public activities. To enhance public understanding of the Monetary Authority’s main Functions, the Monetary Authority held press conferences and media briefing sessions for local, Mainland, and overseas media, covering topics including tokenization, anti-fraud measures, and support measures for SMEs etc. During the year, the Monetary Authority also arranged 25 media interviews, issued about 600 bilingual press releases, and handled a large number of day-to-day media questions.

Chief Executive Yu Wai-man accepted a media interview at “Hong Kong Fintech Week 2024”.

Deputy Chief Executive Mr. Li Dazhi gave a welcoming speech on the date of the “Account linkage” use cases presentation.

Media representatives actively participate in the activity organised by the Hong Kong Monetary Authority in 2024, especially the third International Financial Leaders’ Investment Summit. The summit lasts three days and to effect over ten thousand pieces of local, Mainland and international media news coverage.

Chief Executive Yu Wai-man gave a livestreamed interview to media at the International Financial Leaders’ Investment Summit 2024.

Deputy Chief Executive Mr. Reuben Ng Hong will host a briefing session on the established SME financing Taskforce.

Deputy Chief Executive Mr. Chen Weimin delivered the opening speech at the 2024 corporate treasury summit.

To more effectively connect with the public, the Monetary Authority operates six social media pages (including Facebook, Instagram, LinkedIn, WeChat, X (formerly known as Twitter) and YouTube), with more than 200,000 followers. The Monetary Authority creates creative social media content to enhance public awareness of a range of topics and measures, such as fraud prevention, fintech, green and sustainable finance, support for SMEs, and the Monetary Authority’s major Investment Summit etc. The Monetary Authority also livestreamed the “International Financial Leaders’ Investment Summit” on its social media pages, promote public and industry participation.

Publishing creative content on social media can help increase the public’s understanding of the Hong Kong Monetary Authority’s measures and various topics.

# Public enquiries

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority’s public services provide users with an effective channel to facilitate their understanding of the Authority’s main functions and operations.

In 2024, public queries services handled a total of 9,594 items (Figure 1), all of which were returned within the Hong Kong Monetary Authority performance pledge timeframe (Table 1). About half of these queries involved matters relating to banks, consumers, financial infrastructure and bond market development, banking sector policies and regulations, and banknotes and coins (Figure 2). Common queries included coin collection Scheme, bank products and services, retail bond issuance plan, banking sector related guidance and circulars, and “Faster Payment System”.

Cyber Mapping 1 Public enquiries

Figure 2 lists the queries received in 2024 by nature.

# publications

Within the year, the HKMA published the 《2023 Report》 and the 《2023 Sustainable development report》。The 《2023 Sustainable development report》 was selected and received an award of recognition from the judges in the “Public/non-profit institutions (major)” category at the Hong Kong Institute of Certified Public Accountant(s)’s “Best Corporate Governance and ESG Awards 2024”. In addition, the 《2023 Report》 received a bronze award in the “Non-profit and charitable institutions” category in the Hong Kong Management Association’s annual Best Report selection 2024.

In 2024, the Financial regulatory authority regularly updates the monthly financial data report and publishes it.

14 Exchange articles.

# corporate website

Corporate website (www.hkma.gov.hk) provides 73,000 pages of data in English and Traditional and Simplified Chinese fonts, to facilitate public found of the hkma’s latest information. The website also carries records incorporated under section 20 of the banking sector’s ordinance, namely the “authorized institutions and local representative offices record”, and the “authorized institutions securities business staff record”, as well as records maintained under the payment systems and stored value payment tool ordinance, namely the “stored value payment tool licensed person record”.

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority has, since 2018, through open application programming interfaces (open API), payment financial data and important information published on its website in phases. As at the end of 2024, we have, according to the original plan, launched a total of 177 open API sets on the website. See further information is contained related to the hkma’s open API; please visit the hkma open API gateway website (https://apidocs.hkma.gov.hk).

# Information Centre

The HKMA Information Centre is located on the 55th floor of the International Financial Centre Phase 2, and is divided into an exhibition area and a library, aiming to introduce the HKMA’s work to the public and enhance the public’s understanding of currency and banking sector matters. The exhibition area uses interactive means to introduce the HKMA’s work, as well as the development of Hong Kong’s currency and banking industry; it also provides data and exhibits for study of Hong Kong currency, banking, and financial affairs.

Within the year, the Information Centre received more than 68,000 visitors, an increase of about 120% compared to 2023. The Information Centre also provides the school and other groups with over 570 tours.

The library, located next to the exhibition area, maintains over 26,000 books, journals, and other publications, covering Hong Kong currency, banking, finance, and central bank affairs etc. The library also maintains the “record books of authorized institutions and local representatives’ offices” and “record books of securities business staff of authorized institutions” as required by Section 2 of the Banking Ordinance, for public access.

Kindergarteners participate in a tour of the Information Centre to learn information related to the design of Hong Kong banknotes.

Staff at the Information Centre to introduce a mosaic artwork depicting the Hong Kong skyline, constructed from Hong Kong coins.

# Community linkages and public education

To enhance the public’s understanding of the HKMA’s work, the HKMA has launched public education courses since 1998, and to date, records have exceeded more than 68,000 participants. In 2024, we held online courses, attracted more than 800 users from 41 schools. The content covers About the HKMA, linkages with the exchange rate system, Hong Kong banknotes, anti-fraud, Deposit protection Scheme, green financial opportunities and development in the banking sector.

We use different channels to contact and educate the public, reminding them how to be smart and responsible financial services consumers. The activities in 2024 attracted more than 67,000 users to participate.

To ensure Digital Payment and green living trends, we promote through social media and radio, encourage users to distribute e-red packets during the year, may also consider Payment of physical red packets with a “new welcome banknote”.
